I haven't reviewed yet and just clocked my 160th hour not too long ago so figured I'd shoot.

So far I've liked the game quite a bit. It's a different pace from a game like Tarkov in the sense that the pvp will not feel the same, as well as most other things, but I like the idea that its more of an open world rather than an extraction shooter. Tactics are actually key when clearing larger areas like Midnight Sapphire Hotel or Fort Narith, you can team up with 3 other people to form a squad, and there are A LOT of missions to do. It's a lot more chill than games like Tarkov because you can have almost similar fun while still adhering to your normal schedule. 

It's super enjoyable for the price point, especially with a couple friends, and the upcoming updates seem like they're going to have a lot of great QoL updates. Of course there's always going to be more to refine but MADFINGER actually seems to genuinely care and do their best to apply the communities feedback. Between the content, and adrenaline you get when you randomly get shot at or are clearing a building with friends, you'll get your money's worth out of the base edition but I highly recommend trying to play with friends or at the very least try to make some friends in the game. The community is relatively friendly (sometimes people are just in a mood) and most of the times I've needed or seen anyone who needed help its gotten done.

Some problems you might encounter if you first get the game is some FPS issues at times (like for example certain areas cause CRAZY frame drops when you aim down sight) but you can always try to run your weapon canted and use a laser (although there are certain areas lasers are bugged). Theres also the occasional frustrating random 1 tap or AI in a bush you cant really see but because they're AI they are able to detect you a little better, but they're working on all of these things and they strive to uphold a "same or better, not worse" standard which I can always appreciate, and I look forward to seeing how far this game will go as more and more time passes!

Anyways hope this grants y'all some feedback into whether you should get the game, and if you do I hope you enjoy!

Running on a 3060 Ti and Ryzen 5600X, I still get random crashes but keeping only the game open helps a bit. The game is raw yet promising. Even in this early stage, it already feels closer to Tarkov than anything else on the market.

No long raid queues. No pointless backtracking. You lift off by helicopter and drop straight into the action. The map is fully open world, and missions flow naturally through your radio without forcing you to return to base every time. It keeps the pace fast and immersive.

Combat is intense. Three PMCs fight for control, and friendly fire has heavy consequences. You can switch between PvE and PvP seamlessly, leveling up in one and fighting in the other. Small touches like raising your weapon while wading through water show real design care.

Performance still hurts. FPS drops, crashes, and unstable AI happen often. Landing zones discovered manually feel clunky. Yet the core gameplay loop is there and solid. If the devs stay committed, Gray Zone Warfare can become what Tarkov has been trying to be.

Imma say first I don't know why anybody would want to play this in pvpve, seems like it would be akin to C&B torture. In pve though this is my favourite PMC tactical shooter, like a first person GR wildlands that's tense, has stakes but doesn't need to become your second job just to be able to enjoy and scratches that tactical itch in a way that no other game can for me. The combat is great, the world is immersive and the addition of the weather/time systems adds to that, plus no loading screens when you are in, you physically ride in choppers to get in/out and its always a vibe. 
Also the biggest game-changing change (quite literally) recently is the improvements with the enemy AI that was implemented recently, they are sooooo much better to fight than before, mid/long range engagements actually feel like firefights and they feel more fair while still being deadly, rewarding good repositioning and moving smart. Mind you they are not perfect but even the devs have said that, but what they have done so far is waaay better than before and has got me back into playing since the update. If you are a returning player that was annoyed by the enemies laser zeroing you instantly through foliage, I'd suggest giving it another go.
The only gameplay thing that can be a bit frustrating sometimes is that some of the mission directions can be a bit too vague for me, like I get that its supposed to be immersive but sometimes it askes you to find a needle in a haystack with barely any leads, when that happens I just get a little hint from the wiki cos I haven't got all day, got a life outside of gaming. Obviously I'm not saying they should put big quest markers on the UI or anything like that, but just wish they would use the map coordinates more like the earlier missions do, they help a lot and add to the immersion imo.

Other than that though I love this game, yeah its not perfect its still in active development, but I'd suggest checking out their Youtube channel, you can tell that these are some really passionate and talented people and don't deserve the hate they get online. Salute to you Madfinger keep on cooking!

Mods are by tiers so obviously you will be using the mods with the best stats you can get your hands on. Would make it a lot easier to know if I'm alone or if I have some help nearby if needed.  I'd say the only thing that super annoys me is the damn time restrictions on the quests. Gray Zone Warfare is, in my view, essential for anyone looking to immerse themselves in the operations and atmosphere of a private military company. The game runs exceptionally smoothly, and its visual presentation is outstanding. The overall design ‚Äî from landing zones and forward operating bases to contested PvP areas ‚Äî creates a highly engaging and believable environment.

Combat mechanics are another standout element. Weapon handling and ballistics feel exceptionally well-crafted for a milsim title. The medical system, too, is impressively detailed: dragging unconscious teammates to safety, securing the area with your squad, stitching wounds, administering blood, applying tourniquets, and managing other medical procedures adds depth and tension to every encounter. It‚Äôs one of the most satisfying tactical medical systems I‚Äôve experienced.

The developers embody their motto, ‚ÄúCommunity first.‚Äù They consistently communicate with players, share updates, invite the community to tests, host events, and stream development insights. Their interaction feels genuine and greatly contributes to the positive experience.

The main limitation is the progression system. Acquiring weapon platforms, ammunition types, protective gear, and medical supplies requires significant effort, especially considering the regular wipes ‚Äî typically every major update (around every six months). While these wipes are necessary to maintain balance and integrate new systems, they can be restrictive for milsim enthusiasts who want consistent access to equipment.

A dedicated freeplay or training mode would be highly beneficial. Being able to experiment with different weapon systems, ammunition types, vests, and medical tools ‚Äî alone or with friends ‚Äî would allow players to warm up, practice tactics, and familiarize themselves with the game‚Äôs mechanics without grinding for gear.

Despite the effort required, the progression itself remains enjoyable and offers room for strategic variety depending on your chosen approach and tactical tools. Whether practicing close-quarters engagements (CQB) or open-field battles (OFB), Gray Zone Warfare is an excellent platform for turning theory into practical skill.

Overall, it is a remarkable and carefully crafted game that offers immense value to players who appreciate realistic tactical experiences.

Performance has improved massively since the early builds as well. Weather rolling through the map and proper night time darkness add a level of realism that you notice instantly, especially with the improved lighting.

The sound work helps it all hit harder. Bullets snap past you, footsteps carry properly through the environment, and the whole audio mix finally feels mature. It is genuinely immersive.

Then you have the AI, and this is where the magic starts to fall apart. They still behave like hyper aggressive Rust scientists on steroids. They can snap lock your head from what feels like two hundred metres with an iron sight AK, tank rounds they have no right surviving, and spot you through bushes as if foliage does not exist. Weather does not matter, time of day does not matter, they just know where you are. It feels cheap, and after more than 120 hours it still kills the vibe every time.

The game has the bones of something incredible and visually it is already there, but the AI needs a complete rethink before it reaches its full potential.

Let me preface by saying this game IS fun, but there's a couple things that make it not worth your money. 

Negatives:

 - The graphics are god awful. I would say everything looks really realistic and the lighting is fantastic, but there's some strange fuzzy-looking filter over everything that make it disgusting to look at, on top of that theyre really hardware intensive. For any of my tarkov players out there: the graphics look like the old painkiller effect. It hurts my fucking eyes. 

 - The performance is terrible, and the game LIES about frame rate. I have a pretty good PC, it's not the best, but it's good enough to run any AAA game at AT LEAST 60 FPS with any other programs running in the background. This game runs awfully. It stutters at random times, not a lot mind you, but it does stutter. The frame rate is not very good and for some reason the game lies in the frame counter... While I was playing, I never had my frame rate (according to the counter) drop below 70 fps, most of the time it sat around 90-100 fps. This was a lie. I dont know why the counter is inaccurate, but I recorded footage from the game just to confirm that yes, a MAJORITY of the time I was playing, the game stayed at or below 60 fps, sometimes around 30-40 fps. I checked all my hardware, it's not the fault of my computer, recording software, or monitor, it is the game falsely advertising frames. Why would they do this? who knows. the visual difference between 100 and 50 frames is very apparent to the eyes. FIX YOUR FPS COUNTER.

 - The faction base mechanic. Why is it a thing? it serves absolutely no purpose. It could be entirely replaced by a stash/inventory/traders menu like in ANY OTHER EXTRACT SHOOTER. ALL of the things you interact with in the base to sort your stash, trade with traders, or accept quests, is all in your inventory UI anyway, there's no physical locations you need to go to to do these things, so what's the point? The only thing it does is show off the neat little helicopter ride to/from the home base, which, after your first time doing it, gets annoying. Most heli rides, I'm playing on my phone while I wait for it to drop me off. It's basically at LEAST a 2 minute unskippable cutscene EVERY TIME you infil or exfil. Much longer if youre going further on the map. It's tedious, it's pointless, and most annoyingly, it wastes my fuckin time. 

 - The faction system needs a MAJOR rework. When you first start the game, it asks you to pick a faction to play as. The only information it gives you is a single paragraph of lore background for each organization, so the most you do is go "oh cool this one sounds neat" and pick a random one. What it DOESNT tell you, is that picking a faction will actually affect your gameplay. For one: each faction has similar, but different starting quests and starting locations. Each faction gets a little "starter" town near it's home base, to learn mechanics and do simple quests, and theyre all different. That's not a big issue though, the biggest problem, is that youre UNABLE to play with friends who happened to pick a different faction as you... That is the stupidest thing ever. You have two options: either reset your account and lose all your progress just so you can play with friends, or get fucked. At least in Tarkov, if I chose BEAR and my friend chooses USEC, we can still play together. Nope, not in Gray Zone. The faction system is stupid, and needs a rework, plain and simple.

Positives: 

 - The gunplay is VERY satisfying. The guns feel weighty and realistic. The animations are clean, and the models are very good looking. There is a very satisfying feeling to gunfights, and they often differ a lot depending on your environment: The sound of a snap overhead when youre trudging through a wide open rice field makes your cheeks clench. Laying prone to take more accurate fire, then watching the grass and flowers blow to the sides as gas escapes your muzzle is just, mwah, chef's kiss. Hearing enemies shouting from inside a little wood shack, saying to yourself, "fuck that shit, I'm not going in there" then proceeding to dump 3 mags of 7.62 through the walls, and listening to the bodies drop on the other side... Then throwing a grenade in a window too, just for good measure. Firefights with both players and the AI are fun... they did a good job with the gunplay, and the AI behavior. 

 - The health mechanics are very well done. Not a lot to say here besides that it's realistic enough to be engaging, but not realistic enough to make the game miserable. Honestly a better healing system than tarkov in my opinion. On top of that the hitboxes are VERY precise, it's very impressive how well they did it. I like the feature where you can see the enemy's health UI when youre looting them, so you can see where you hit them, it's immersive and satisfying.  

 - it's only $40, most AAA games are making you pay $70 for their dogwater games. At least this is dogwater at a discount. Enough said there. 

Overall: 

If they fixed some of the things that I mentioned in the beginning, I would highly recommend this game, but I highly doubt they will to be honest. The gameplay is fun enough to WANT to ignore the issues with the game, but theyre just really hard to ignore. I wouldnt recommend anyone buy it in it's current state. Play another extract shooter that's actually fun, like Hunt Showdown.
